text: What is the SI unit of work?
explanation: The SI unit of work is Joule (J).

text: When is work said to be done?

options.text: When force is applied to an object
When an object moves in the direction of the applied force
When an object is at rest
When an object changes its shape

explanation: Work is done when a force causes displacement of an object in the direction of the force.

text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
explanation: Work is a scalar quantity, meaning it only has magnitude and no direction.

text: What is the formula for work done?
explanation: The formula for work done is Work = Force × Displacement (when force and displacement are in the same direction).

text: If a force of 10 N moves an object by 5 m in the direction of the force, what is the work done?
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement = 10 N × 5 m = 50 J.

text: What is energy defined as?

options.text: The rate at which work is done
The force applied to an object

explanation: Energy is defined as the capacity or ability to do work.

text: What is the SI unit of energy?
explanation: The SI unit of energy is Joule (J).

text: Which of the following is a form of mechanical energy?
explanation: Mechanical energy includes kinetic energy (energy of motion) and potential energy (stored energy due to position or state).

text: What type of energy does a moving car possess?
explanation: A moving car possesses kinetic energy due to its motion.

text: What type of energy does water stored in a dam possess?
explanation: Water stored at a height in a dam possesses gravitational potential energy.

text: What is the formula for kinetic energy?
explanation: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 mv², where m is mass and v is velocity.

text: What is the formula for gravitational potential energy?
explanation: The formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = mgh, where m is mass, g is acceleration due to gravity, and h is height.

text: A 2 kg object is moving at a speed of 3 m/s. What is its kinetic energy?
A 5 kg object is raised to a height of 2 m. What is its potential energy? (Assume g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: PE = mgh = 5 kg × 10 m/s² × 2 m = 100 J.

text: What does the law of conservation of energy state?

options.text: Energy can be created and destroyed.
Energy can only be converted from one form to another.
Energy is always lost as heat.
Energy is constant in a closed system.

explanation: The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed; it can only be transformed from one form to another.

text: When a ball is thrown upwards, what happens to its kinetic energy as it rises?
explanation: As a ball rises, its speed decreases, and thus its kinetic energy decreases, converting into potential energy.

text: At the highest point of its trajectory, what type of energy does a ball thrown upwards primarily have?
explanation: At the highest point, the ball momentarily stops moving vertically, so its kinetic energy is zero, and its potential energy is maximum.

text: What is power defined as?

options.text: The force applied over a distance

explanation: Power is defined as the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.

text: What is the SI unit of power?
explanation: The SI unit of power is Watt (W).

text: If 100 J of work is done in 10 seconds, what is the power?
explanation: Power = Work / Time = 100 J / 10 s = 10 W.

text: Which of the following is NOT a unit of energy?
explanation: Horsepower is a unit of power, while calorie, kilowatt-hour, and erg are units of energy.

text: What type of energy is stored in a stretched spring?
explanation: A stretched or compressed spring stores elastic potential energy.

text: Which of the following activities involves work done against gravity?

options.text: Lifting a book from the floor

explanation: Lifting a book involves applying a force upwards against the downward force of gravity, resulting in displacement in the direction of the applied force.

text: What happens to the kinetic energy of an object if its velocity is doubled?
explanation: Since KE = 1/2 mv², if velocity (v) is doubled, v² becomes (2v)² = 4v², so kinetic energy quadruples.

text: What type of energy conversion occurs in a hydroelectric power plant?
explanation: In a hydroelectric plant, the potential energy of water is converted to kinetic energy as it falls, which then turns turbines to generate electrical energy.

text: In physics, for work to be done, there must be:
explanation: Work is done only when a force is applied and there is a displacement in the direction of the force.

text: Which of the following statements is true about work?

options.text: Work can be positive, negative, or zero.

explanation: Work can be positive (force and displacement in the same direction), negative (force and displacement in opposite directions), or zero (no displacement or force perpendicular to displacement).

text: When is the work done by a force zero?

options.text: When the force is very large.
When the force and displacement are in the same direction.
When the object moves at a constant velocity.

explanation: Work done is zero if there is no displacement, or if the force is perpendicular to the displacement.

text: A boy tries to push a heavy rock but it does not move. What is the work done by the boy?

options.text: Work equal to the force applied

explanation: Since the rock does not move, the displacement is zero, and therefore, no work is done.

text: What is the relationship between work and energy?

options.text: Work is always greater than energy.
Work is done when energy is transferred or transformed.
Energy is always lost during work.

explanation: Work is a measure of energy transfer. When work is done, energy is transferred from one form to another or from one object to another.

text: Which of the following is an example of kinetic energy?
explanation: A flowing river has kinetic energy due to the motion of water.

text: Which of the following is an example of potential energy?

options.text: A car parked on a hill

explanation: A car parked on a hill has gravitational potential energy due to its height.

text: What is the unit of power often used for electric motors?
explanation: Horsepower is a common unit of power, especially for engines and motors.

text: If you lift a 20 N weight by 1 meter, how much work have you done?
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement = 20 N × 1 m = 20 J.

text: An object has a mass of 10 kg and is moving at 5 m/s. Its kinetic energy is:
Which of the following devices converts electrical energy into mechanical energy?
explanation: An electric motor uses electrical energy to produce motion (mechanical energy).

text: What type of energy is possessed by a book resting on a table?
explanation: A book resting on a table has gravitational potential energy due to its height above the ground.

text: A person runs up a flight of stairs. Which concept is most relevant to the speed at which they run?
explanation: Power relates to the rate of doing work. Running faster means doing work (lifting their body against gravity) in less time, which means more power.

text: If a ball is dropped from a certain height, what happens to its potential energy as it falls?
explanation: As a ball falls, its height decreases, so its gravitational potential energy decreases, converting into kinetic energy.

text: What is the common term for the sum of kinetic and potential energy?
explanation: The sum of kinetic energy and potential energy is known as mechanical energy.

text: Which of the following is NOT an example of energy transformation?

options.text: A car sitting in a garage

explanation: A car sitting in a garage is at rest and does not involve energy transformation; it has potential energy but is not actively converting it.

text: The energy stored in food is an example of what type of energy?
explanation: Food contains stored chemical energy that can be released through metabolic processes.

text: What does a joule represent in terms of force and distance?
explanation: A Joule is defined as the work done when a force of one Newton moves an object by one meter (1 J = 1 N·m).

text: When you compress a spring, what happens to the work you do?

options.text: It is converted into kinetic energy.
It is stored as elastic potential energy.

explanation: Work done in compressing a spring is stored as elastic potential energy within the spring.

text: What is the relationship between work and power?

options.text: Power is work done per unit time.
Work is power done per unit time.
Power is the cause of work.

explanation: Power is the rate at which work is done, or work divided by time.

text: A crane lifts a 500 kg load to a height of 10 m in 5 seconds. What is the power of the crane? (Assume g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: Work = mgh = 500 kg × 10 m/s² × 10 m = 50000 J. Power = Work / Time = 50000 J / 5 s = 10000 W.

text: Which form of energy is stored in fossil fuels?
explanation: Fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas store chemical energy.

text: What type of work is done when a satellite orbits the Earth in a circular path?

options.text: Work equal to the gravitational force

explanation: The gravitational force acts towards the center of the Earth (perpendicular to the displacement), so no work is done by gravity on a satellite in a circular orbit.

text: What happens to total mechanical energy in an ideal system (no friction)?
explanation: In the absence of non-conservative forces like friction, the total mechanical energy of a system remains conserved.

text: Which of the following is a renewable source of energy?
explanation: Solar energy is considered a renewable energy source because it is continuously replenished by the sun.

text: Which of the following is a non-renewable source of energy?
explanation: Nuclear energy derived from uranium is considered non-renewable because uranium is a finite resource.

text: What is the energy conversion in a simple battery powering a flashlight?

options.text: Chemical energy to electrical energy to light energy

explanation: A battery stores chemical energy, converts it to electrical energy, which then powers the flashlight bulb to produce light.

text: If you push a block horizontally across a frictionless surface, what is the work done by the normal force?
explanation: The normal force is perpendicular to the horizontal displacement, so the work done by the normal force is zero.

text: What is the relationship between potential energy and stability?

options.text: Higher potential energy means higher stability.
Higher potential energy means lower stability.
Potential energy and stability are unrelated.
Lower potential energy means lower stability.

explanation: Objects tend to move towards a state of lower potential energy, which corresponds to higher stability.

text: A light bulb converts electrical energy into which two main forms of energy?
explanation: A light bulb primarily produces light and also generates heat as a byproduct.

text: What is the unit of work in the CGS system?
explanation: The unit of work in the CGS (centimeter-gram-second) system is erg.

text: What is the primary energy source for most living organisms on Earth?
explanation: The sun is the ultimate source of energy for most life on Earth through photosynthesis.

text: When a force does negative work on an object, what happens to the object's kinetic energy?
explanation: Negative work implies that the force opposes the motion, thus reducing the object's kinetic energy.

text: What is the commercial unit of electrical energy?
explanation: Kilowatt-hour (kWh) is the commercial unit for measuring electrical energy consumption.

text: One kilowatt-hour (kWh) is equivalent to how many joules?
Which of the following describes the energy transformation in a speaker?
explanation: A speaker converts electrical signals into sound waves.

text: What form of energy is associated with the temperature of an object?
explanation: Thermal energy is related to the random motion of atoms and molecules within an object, which determines its temperature.

text: If a person carries a bag horizontally across a flat road, what is the work done by the person on the bag against gravity?

options.text: Work equal to the weight of the bag

explanation: The force applied by the person to support the bag is upwards, while the displacement is horizontal. Since force and displacement are perpendicular, the work done against gravity is zero.

text: What is the principle behind a swing set?

options.text: Conservation of mechanical energy (potential and kinetic)

explanation: A swing demonstrates the continuous conversion between potential and kinetic energy, assuming negligible air resistance and friction.

text: Which of the following statements about energy is correct?

options.text: Energy can be seen and touched.
Energy is a physical quantity that measures the ability to do work.
Energy is always consumed, never conserved.
Energy only exists in one form.

explanation: Energy is a measure of the capacity to do work.

text: What is the force required to do 200 J of work over a distance of 10 m?
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement, so Force = Work / Displacement = 200 J / 10 m = 20 N.

text: Which factor has the largest effect on the kinetic energy of an object?
explanation: Kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (v²), so a change in velocity has a greater impact than a change in mass.

text: A diver on a high platform has what type of energy?
explanation: A diver on a high platform possesses gravitational potential energy due to their elevated position.

text: What is the primary function of a lever in terms of work and energy?

options.text: To increase the total work done.
To change the direction or magnitude of force.

explanation: Levers (and other simple machines) are used to multiply force or change its direction, making work easier, but they do not increase the total work done.

text: A person pushing a shopping cart does work on the cart. What force is responsible for this work?
explanation: The applied force from the person pushing the cart is responsible for the work done to move the cart.

text: Which of the following involves zero work done?

options.text: Pushing a box across a room.
Pulling a sled up a hill.

explanation: If an object is held stationary, there is no displacement, so no work is done.

text: What is the energy conversion when a matchstick is struck and burns?
explanation: The chemical energy stored in the matchstick and its head is released as heat and light when it burns.

text: A roller coaster car is at the top of a hill. What type of energy does it predominantly have?
explanation: At the top of the hill, the roller coaster car has maximum gravitational potential energy.

text: As the roller coaster car goes down the hill, what happens to its potential energy?
explanation: As the car goes down, its height decreases, so its potential energy decreases, converting into kinetic energy.

text: What is the relationship between gravitational potential energy and the mass of an object?
explanation: From PE = mgh, potential energy is directly proportional to mass (m).

text: A child pulls a toy car with a force of 5 N for a distance of 3 m. How much work is done?
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement = 5 N × 3 m = 15 J.

text: Which of the following requires the most work?

options.text: Lifting a 1 kg mass by 1 m.
Lifting a 2 kg mass by 0.5 m.
Pushing a 10 kg mass horizontally by 1 m (no friction).
Holding a 5 kg mass for 1 minute.

explanation: a) Work = mgh = 1 kg * g * 1 m = g J. b) Work = mgh = 2 kg * g * 0.5 m = g J. c) Work is zero in ideal frictionless horizontal motion. d) Work is zero as no displacement. So a and b are equal and greater than c and d. Assuming g=10, they are 10J.

text: What is the form of energy associated with the motion of atoms and molecules?
explanation: Thermal energy is the internal energy of a system due to the microscopic motion of its particles.

text: In a pendulum, where is kinetic energy maximum?

options.text: At the highest points of its swing.
At the lowest point of its swing.
It is constant throughout the swing.

explanation: Kinetic energy is maximum when the pendulum bob has its highest speed, which occurs at the lowest point of its swing.

text: In a pendulum, where is potential energy maximum?

options.text: At the highest points of its swing.
At the lowest point of its swing.
It is constant throughout the swing.

explanation: Potential energy is maximum when the pendulum bob is at its highest vertical position during its swing.

text: What type of energy is transformed into electrical energy in a solar panel?
explanation: Solar panels convert light energy from the sun directly into electrical energy.

text: What is the relationship between work and friction?
explanation: Friction always opposes motion, so it does negative work, converting mechanical energy into heat.

text: If a person climbs a mountain, what kind of energy increases?
explanation: As a person climbs higher, their gravitational potential energy increases.

text: What is the primary energy conversion in a wind turbine?
explanation: Wind turbines convert the kinetic energy of wind into electrical energy.

text: Which of the following best describes the energy of sound?
explanation: Sound is a form of mechanical energy that travels as vibrations through a medium.

text: A person pulls a block with a force of 20 N. If the work done is 60 J, what is the distance the block moved?
explanation: Distance = Work / Force = 60 J / 20 N = 3 m.

text: What is the relationship between work, force, and displacement?
explanation: Work is calculated as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force.

text: An object has 50 J of kinetic energy. If its mass is doubled and its velocity is halved, what is its new kinetic energy?
What type of energy is released during nuclear fission or fusion?
explanation: Nuclear fission and fusion reactions release enormous amounts of nuclear energy from the nucleus of atoms.

text: Which of these devices primarily converts electrical energy into heat energy?
explanation: An electric heater is designed to convert electrical energy into heat.

text: The energy of moving water in a river is an example of:
explanation: Moving water possesses kinetic energy due to its motion.

text: If a person carries a suitcase and walks on a horizontal surface, the work done by the person on the suitcase is:
explanation: The force applied to carry the suitcase is upwards, perpendicular to the horizontal displacement, so no work is done.

text: What is the work done against friction if a box is pulled 5 m with a frictional force of 10 N opposing the motion?
explanation: Work done by friction is negative because it opposes displacement: Work = Force × Displacement = -10 N × 5 m = -50 J.

text: What is the purpose of the 'Work-Energy Theorem'?

options.text: To calculate the potential energy of an object.
To relate the net work done on an object to its change in kinetic energy.
To determine the acceleration of an object.
To find the force acting on an object.

explanation: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the net work done on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy (W_net = ΔKE).

text: Which of the following is an example of an object doing work?

options.text: A book sitting on a table.
A person pushing a car that moves.
A wall holding up a roof.
A battery in a remote control, not being used.

explanation: A person pushing a car that moves means force is applied and there is displacement, hence work is done.

text: What does a larger power output mean for a machine?
explanation: Greater power means more work done per unit of time, so the work is done faster.

text: What type of energy is stored in a spring when it is compressed?
explanation: A compressed spring stores elastic potential energy.

text: What is the main energy conversion in a firecracker?

options.text: Chemical to sound, light, and heat

explanation: A firecracker's explosion converts chemical energy into sound, light, and heat.

text: What happens to the energy when a car brakes and stops?

options.text: It is converted to potential energy.
It is converted to heat and sound energy due to friction.
It is stored as chemical energy.

explanation: During braking, the kinetic energy of the car is converted primarily into heat due to friction in the brakes and some sound.

text: If you lift a 10 kg mass by 5 m, how much potential energy does it gain? (g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: PE = mgh = 10 kg × 10 m/s² × 5 m = 500 J.

text: Which statement best describes the concept of a 'conservative force'?

options.text: A force that always opposes motion.
A force for which the work done depends on the path taken.
A force for which the work done is independent of the path taken.
A force that converts kinetic energy into heat.

explanation: For a conservative force, the work done moving an object between two points depends only on the initial and final positions, not on the path taken (e.g., gravity, spring force).

text: Which of the following is an example of a non-conservative force?
explanation: Frictional force is a non-conservative force because the work done by friction depends on the path length traveled.

text: When a stretched rubber band is released, its elastic potential energy is converted into what form of energy?
explanation: As the rubber band snaps back, its stored elastic potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of its motion.

text: What is the relationship between power and time if work done is constant?
explanation: Since Power = Work / Time, if work is constant, power is inversely proportional to time (less time means more power).

text: A car accelerates from rest. What type of energy is increasing?
explanation: As the car accelerates, its speed increases, and therefore its kinetic energy increases.

text: What does a positive value of work done indicate?

options.text: Energy is being removed from the object.
Energy is being added to the object.

explanation: Positive work means that the force is in the direction of displacement, adding energy to the object.

text: What does a negative value of work done indicate?

options.text: Energy is being added to the object.
Energy is being removed from the object.

explanation: Negative work means that the force opposes the displacement, removing energy from the object.

text: What is the energy transformation when you rub your hands together?
explanation: Rubbing hands together involves mechanical work against friction, which generates heat.

text: What is the energy of a stretched bow and arrow?
explanation: A stretched bow and arrow store elastic potential energy.

text: When the arrow is released from the bow, what energy transformation occurs?
explanation: The elastic potential energy stored in the stretched bow is converted into kinetic energy of the arrow.

text: What is the definition of efficiency in terms of energy?

options.text: Energy input divided by energy output.
Energy output divided by energy input.

explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful energy output to total energy input, usually expressed as a percentage.

text: Can efficiency ever be 100% in real-world energy conversions?

options.text: Only if there is no friction.

explanation: Due to the second law of thermodynamics (and practical factors like friction and heat loss), no real-world energy conversion can be 100% efficient.

text: What is the energy conversion in a flashlight?
explanation: A flashlight converts the chemical energy stored in its battery into light energy.

text: A boy pulls a cart with a force of 10 N at an angle of 30 degrees to the horizontal. The cart moves 5 m horizontally. Is the work done 50 J?
explanation: Work = Force × Displacement × cos(angle). Since cos(30°) is less than 1, the work done will be less than 50 J.

text: What is the energy of a compressed gas?
explanation: A compressed gas stores energy due to the pressure exerted on it, often referred to as pressure potential energy or internal energy.

text: Which of these is a form of energy that we can feel as warmth?
explanation: Thermal energy is associated with the temperature of an object and is what we perceive as heat or warmth.

text: What is the energy conversion in a microphone?
explanation: A microphone converts sound waves (mechanical energy) into electrical signals.

text: Why is 'Work done' considered a scalar quantity?

options.text: Because it has both magnitude and direction.

explanation: Work is a scalar quantity because it is defined by its magnitude (the amount of energy transferred) and does not have a specific direction.

text: What is the minimum force required to lift a 5 kg object? (g = 10 m/s²)
explanation: The force required is equal to the weight of the object, F = mg = 5 kg × 10 m/s² = 50 N.

text: If a body's speed is reduced to half, its kinetic energy becomes:
explanation: KE = 1/2 mv². If v becomes v/2, then v² becomes (v/2)² = v²/4. So, KE becomes one-fourth of the original.

text: What type of energy is associated with electromagnetic waves?
explanation: Light, radio waves, X-rays, etc., are forms of radiant or electromagnetic energy.

text: What is the total energy of a falling object at any point (ignoring air resistance)?

options.text: A constant sum of kinetic and potential energy.

explanation: According to the law of conservation of mechanical energy (in ideal conditions), the sum of kinetic and potential energy remains constant.

text: When a force is applied to an object but it doesn't move, what is the work done?
explanation: If there is no displacement, no work is done, even if a force is applied.

text: Which of these processes is an example of work being done?

options.text: A person thinking about a problem.
A car pushing a stalled car forward.

explanation: A car pushing a stalled car forward involves applying a force and causing displacement, thus performing work.

text: What is the relationship between power and the amount of work done?

options.text: Power is directly proportional to work done.
Power is inversely proportional to work done.
Power is independent of work done.
Power is the square of work done.

explanation: For a given time, power is directly proportional to the amount of work done (P = W/t).

text: Which of the following describes an object in motion?

options.text: Its position is not changing with respect to its surroundings.
Its position is changing with respect to its surroundings.
It has a constant velocity of zero.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: When is an object said to be at rest?

options.text: When its position is changing rapidly.
When its position is not changing with respect to its surroundings.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: Motion is considered a ______ concept.
explanation: The text states that motion is a relative concept[cite: 265].

text: Which of the following is an example of an object at rest?
explanation: A stationary train is given as an example of an object at rest[cite: 272].

text: What is the primary factor used to determine if an object is moving?

options.text: Its position relative to its surroundings.

explanation: To decide if an object is moving or not, one takes into consideration if its position is changing with respect to its surroundings[cite: 265].

text: Can the motion of an object always be seen directly?

options.text: No, sometimes it cannot be seen directly.
Only if the object is very large.
Only if the object is very fast.

explanation: Sometimes we cannot see the motion of an object directly, as in the case of a breeze[cite: 267].

text: What is 'distance' in physics?

options.text: The shortest path between two points.
The final position of an object.
The total length of the actual path travelled by an object.
The rate of change of displacement.

explanation: Distance is the length of the actual path travelled by an object[cite: 305].

text: What is 'displacement' in physics?

options.text: The shortest distance between the initial and final positions of an object.

explanation: Displacement refers to the shortest distance between the starting and ending points of an object's motion, which is implicitly explained by contrasting it with 'actual distance travelled' and discussions about an object returning to its starting point having zero displacement[cite: 272, 297].

text: If an object moves from point A to point B and then returns to point A, what is its total displacement?

options.text: Equal to the total distance travelled.
Twice the distance from A to B.
Half the distance from A to B.

explanation: Even if the displacement of an object is zero, the actual distance traversed by it may not be zero. This implies that if an object returns to its starting point, its displacement is zero[cite: 297].

text: Which of the following is related to 'distance'?
explanation: Speed is related to distance while velocity is related to the displacement[cite: 300].

text: What is the SI unit of speed?
explanation: In the SI system, the unit for speed and velocity is m/s[cite: 299].

text: What is the CGS unit of velocity?
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit for speed and velocity is cm/s[cite: 299].

text: Velocity is defined as the displacement that occurs in ______.
explanation: Velocity is the displacement that occurs in unit time[cite: 302, 304].

text: When are the values of speed and velocity the same?

options.text: Only when the object is at rest.
When the motion is along a curved path.
When the motion is along a straight line.

explanation: If the motion is along a straight line, the values of speed and velocity are the same[cite: 301].

text: How can the velocity of a motorcycle change?

options.text: By changing the speed while keeping the direction same.
By only changing the tire pressure.

explanation: Velocity changes by changing the speed while keeping the direction same[cite: 329].

text: An object's inertia is related to its ______.
explanation: Inertia is related to the mass of the object[cite: 344, 362].

text: Which of Newton's laws of motion is also called the law of inertia?
explanation: Newton’s first law of motion describes this very property (inertia) and is therefore also called the law of inertia[cite: 345, 363].

text: According to Newton's first law, what happens to a static object without the application of a force?
explanation: A static object does not move without the application of a force[cite: 339, 357].

text: What does inertia describe about an object?

options.text: Its resistance to changes in motion.

explanation: Inertia is the property of objects that makes them resist changes in their state of motion or rest. This is implied by the examples given, such as a static object not moving without force, and a fan continuing to rotate after being switched off[cite: 339, 342, 343, 357, 360, 361].

text: A car travels 50 km to the East and then 50 km to the West. What is the total distance traveled?
explanation: Distance is the total length of the actual path travelled. So, 50 km + 50 km = 100 km[cite: 305].

text: A person walks 5 km North, then 3 km South. What is their displacement?
explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance from the initial to the final position. Walking 5 km North and then 3 km South results in a net displacement of 5 - 3 = 2 km North. This demonstrates the concept of displacement as distinct from total distance[cite: 272, 297].

text: If an object travels in a straight line, how does its speed compare to its velocity?

options.text: Speed is always greater than velocity.
Velocity is always greater than speed.

explanation: If the motion is along a straight line, the values of speed and velocity are the same[cite: 301].

text: What happens to the velocity of a motorcycle if its speed increases but its direction remains unchanged?
explanation: Velocity changes by changing the speed while keeping the direction same. If speed increases, velocity increases[cite: 325, 329].

text: When an object changes its direction while keeping its speed constant, what happens to its velocity?
explanation: Velocity changes by changing the direction while keeping the speed same[cite: 327, 329].

text: Which of the following is an example of motion?

options.text: A stone lying on a hill.

explanation: The flight of a bird is given as an example of motion[cite: 272].

text: What is the relationship between an object's mass and its inertia?

options.text: Inertia is inversely proportional to mass.
Inertia is directly related to mass.

explanation: We have learnt that inertia is related to the mass of the object[cite: 344, 362]. This implies a direct relationship: greater mass means greater inertia.

text: If a force is sufficient to lift a book, why might it not be sufficient to lift a table?

options.text: The book has more inertia than the table.
The table has more inertia than the book.
The book is made of a different material.

explanation: This situation illustrates that objects have some inertia, and inertia is related to mass. A table has significantly more mass (and thus inertia) than a book, requiring a greater force to move it[cite: 340, 343, 358, 361].

text: Why do fruits fall down when tree branches are shaken?

options.text: Due to the law of inertia.

explanation: This is an example given to explain inertia. The fruits tend to remain at rest (due to inertia) even when the branch moves, causing them to detach and fall[cite: 341, 343, 359, 361].

text: What is 'velocity'?

options.text: The length of the path covered.
The displacement that occurs in unit time.
The change in speed over time.

explanation: Velocity is the displacement that occurs in unit time[cite: 302, 304].

text: What is the primary difference between distance and displacement?

options.text: Distance is always negative, displacement is positive.
Distance is a scalar quantity, displacement is a vector quantity.
Distance is measured in meters, displacement in kilometers.
There is no difference, they are the same.

explanation: The text implies this by defining distance as 'length of the actual path' and displacement as a directional change (shortest distance from initial to final position), with examples where displacement can be zero while distance is not. This distinction points to distance being scalar (magnitude only) and displacement being vector (magnitude and direction)[cite: 272, 297, 305].

text: If an electric fan keeps on rotating for some time even after it is switched off, this demonstrates the concept of:
explanation: This example is used to explain the concept of inertia, which is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion[cite: 342, 343, 360, 361].

text: Which of the following units can be used for 'unit time' when defining velocity?

options.text: One second, one minute, one hour, or even one year.
Time is not relevant for velocity.

explanation: Here, unit time can be one second, one minute, one hour, etc. If large units are used, one year can also be used as a unit of time[cite: 303].

text: If a bus is moving, and you are sitting next to another person, is the person next to you in motion relative to you?

options.text: No, because their position relative to you is not changing.
Only if the bus changes speed.
Only if the bus changes direction.

explanation: Motion is a relative concept. If the person's position is not changing with respect to your position (their surroundings from your perspective), then they are at rest relative to you, even if the bus is moving[cite: 265].

text: A ball rolls 10 meters east, then 10 meters west. What is the total distance traveled?
explanation: Distance is the total length of the actual path travelled. So, 10 meters + 10 meters = 20 meters[cite: 305].

text: What is the displacement of an object if it starts at point X and ends at point X?
explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance between the initial and final positions. If an object ends at its starting point, its displacement is zero[cite: 297].

text: Which of the following is an example where velocity changes due to a change in direction while keeping speed constant?

options.text: A car speeding up on a straight road.
A car braking to a stop.
A car going around a circular turn at a constant speed.

explanation: Velocity depends on both speed and direction. If the direction changes, even with constant speed, the velocity changes[cite: 327, 329]. A circular turn is a classic example of this.

text: Newton's first law of motion explains which property of objects?
explanation: Newton’s first law of motion describes this very property (inertia)[cite: 345, 363].

text: What is the condition for an object to be considered 'at rest'?

options.text: It is not moving at all.
Its position is not changing with respect to its surroundings.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: If a car's speedometer reads 60 km/h, what is this measuring?
explanation: A speedometer measures the magnitude of motion, which is speed. Velocity would require a direction as well[cite: 300].

text: A runner completes one lap around a 400m circular track. What is their displacement?
explanation: If a runner completes one full lap, they return to their starting position. Therefore, their displacement is zero[cite: 297].

text: Which of the following would result in a change in velocity?

options.text: Changing only the direction of motion.
Changing only the speed of motion.
Changing both speed and direction of motion.

explanation: Velocity changes by 1. changing the speed while keeping the direction same, 2. changing the direction while keeping the speed same, 3. changing both the speed and direction[cite: 329].

text: If an object is said to be in motion, what must be happening?

options.text: Its position is changing relative to a reference point.
It is always moving in a straight line.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: Why does a stationary object not move without the application of a force?
explanation: If we look for reasons for the above (a static object not moving without force), we realize that objects have some inertia[cite: 339, 343, 357, 361].

text: Which quantity is related to 'displacement'?
explanation: Velocity is related to the displacement[cite: 300].

text: The unit of velocity in the SI system is the same as the unit of:
explanation: The units of speed and velocity are the same. In the SI system, the unit is m/s[cite: 298, 299].

text: What does it mean for motion to be a 'relative concept'?

options.text: Motion is always the same for all observers.
Whether an object is in motion depends on the observer's frame of reference.
Motion is a concept only applicable to relatives.
Motion only occurs when objects are physically touching.

explanation: Motion is a relative concept, meaning an object's motion is determined by its position changing with respect to its surroundings (or observer's frame of reference)[cite: 265].

text: If an object travels 100 meters and its displacement is 50 meters, what can be inferred about its path?

options.text: It traveled in a straight line.
It returned to its starting point.
It did not travel in a straight line.

explanation: If the motion is along a straight line, the values of speed and velocity (and thus distance and displacement) are the same. Since distance (100m) is not equal to displacement (50m), the motion was not along a straight line[cite: 301].

text: Which of the following is an example of an object in motion?

options.text: A car parked on the street.

explanation: Leaves flying through air is given as an example of motion[cite: 272].

text: What characteristic defines an object that is 'at rest'?

options.text: Its position is not changing relative to its surroundings.
It is made of a certain material.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: If a car goes from point P to point Q and then immediately back to point P, what is its total displacement?

options.text: The distance from P to Q.
Twice the distance from P to Q.
Half the distance from P to Q.

explanation: If a car, starting from point P, goes to point Q and then returns to point P, its displacement is zero because the final position is the same as the initial position[cite: 296, 297].

text: What is the relationship between velocity, displacement, and time?
explanation: Velocity is the displacement that occurs in unit time, which implies Velocity = Displacement / Time[cite: 302, 304].

text: In the CGS system, what are the units of speed and velocity?
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit is cm/s[cite: 299].

text: Which of the following is true about velocity?

options.text: It depends on both speed and direction.

explanation: It is clear from the above that velocity depends on speed as well as direction[cite: 329].

text: The property of objects to resist changes in their state of motion or rest is called:
explanation: Objects have some inertia. We have learnt that inertia is related to the mass of the object. Newton’s first law of motion describes this very property[cite: 343, 344, 345, 361, 362, 363].

text: Why does a static object require a force to move?
explanation: A static object does not move without the application of a force, because objects have some inertia[cite: 339, 343, 357, 361].

text: Which of the following describes the 'state of rest' for an object?

options.text: Its position is fixed relative to its surroundings.
It is under the influence of strong forces.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: If a car travels at a constant speed around a curve, what happens to its velocity?

options.text: It changes due to a change in direction.

explanation: Velocity depends on both speed and direction. Even if speed is constant, a change in direction (like on a curve) will change the velocity[cite: 327, 329].

text: Consider two objects, A and B. Object A has a larger mass than object B. Which object has more inertia?

options.text: Inertia is not related to mass.

explanation: Inertia is related to the mass of the object[cite: 344, 362]. A larger mass implies greater inertia.

text: Which of the following is an accurate definition of motion?

options.text: The object is always speeding up.
The object is always slowing down.
The position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: A path has two points, A and B. If you measure the distance along a winding path between A and B, and also measure the straight line distance, which represents the displacement?
explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance between the initial and final positions, which is represented by the straight line distance[cite: 272, 297].

text: If an object travels 10 meters East, and then 10 meters West, what is its displacement?
explanation: Displacement is the change in position from start to end. Since the object returns to its starting point, the displacement is zero[cite: 297].

text: The concept of an object resisting a change in its state of motion or rest is explained by:
explanation: Objects have some inertia, which makes them resist changes in motion or rest[cite: 343, 361].

text: Which of the following statements about speed and velocity is correct?

options.text: Speed and velocity are always the same.
Speed is a vector, velocity is a scalar.
Speed is related to distance, while velocity is related to displacement.
Velocity can be negative, speed cannot.

explanation: Speed is related to distance while velocity is related to the displacement[cite: 300].

text: Why do some objects continue to move after the force causing their motion is removed?
explanation: An electric fan keeps on rotating for some time even after it is switched off due to inertia[cite: 342, 343, 360, 361].

text: What is the key difference when comparing the distance and displacement of an object?

options.text: Distance includes direction, displacement does not.
Displacement includes direction, distance does not.
Distance is always smaller than displacement.
Displacement is always larger than distance.

explanation: Distance is the total path length (scalar), while displacement is the shortest path from start to end with direction (vector). The text highlights the distinction by showing displacement can be zero even if distance is not[cite: 272, 297, 305].

text: Which of the following is a unit of velocity in the SI system?
explanation: In the SI system, the unit is m/s[cite: 299].

text: If an object's speed is constant but its direction changes, its velocity will:

options.text: Only change if speed also changes.

explanation: Velocity changes by changing the direction while keeping the speed same[cite: 327, 329].

text: Newton's first law of motion is often referred to as the law of:
explanation: Newton’s first law of motion... is therefore also called the law of inertia[cite: 345, 363].

text: What is the state of an object if its position does not change with respect to its surroundings?
explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: The actual distance covered by an object is called its:
explanation: Distance is the length of the actual path travelled by an object[cite: 305].

text: A static object will remain static unless what is applied to it?
explanation: A static object does not move without the application of a force[cite: 339, 357].

text: If an object's velocity and speed are different, what can be concluded about its motion?

options.text: It is moving in a straight line.
Its motion is not along a straight line.

explanation: If the motion is along a straight line, the values of speed and velocity are the same, otherwise they can be different[cite: 301]. Therefore, if they are different, the motion is not in a straight line.

text: Which of the following scenarios always results in zero displacement?

options.text: Moving in a straight line forward.

explanation: Even if the displacement of an object is zero, the actual distance traversed by it may not be zero. This happens when an object returns to its starting point[cite: 297].

text: The examples of 'flight of a bird' and 'leaves flying through air' are used to illustrate what concept?
explanation: These are given as examples of motion.

text: Which of the following correctly describes 'inertia'?

options.text: The total distance an object travels.
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion or rest.
The change in velocity over time.

explanation: Inertia is the property that objects have which makes them resist movement if static, or resist changes in motion if moving[cite: 343, 361].

text: When defining velocity, 'unit time' can refer to:

options.text: One second, one minute, one hour, or even one year.
The time it takes to stop.

explanation: Unit time can be one second, one minute, one hour, etc. If large units are used, one year can also be used as a unit of time[cite: 303].

text: What is the key idea behind 'motion being a relative concept'?

options.text: All motion is the same for everyone.
Motion depends on the observer's viewpoint.
Motion only happens in relation to gravity.

explanation: Motion is a relative concept, meaning it's judged based on an object's position changing with respect to its surroundings[cite: 265].

text: If an object covers a large distance but its displacement is small, what does this indicate?

options.text: It moved in a straight line.
It moved in a complex or non-straight path.
It was at rest for most of the time.

explanation: When distance and displacement are different, it implies that the motion was not along a straight line[cite: 301]. A large distance with small displacement suggests a winding or back-and-forth path.

text: When is an object considered to be in 'motion'?

options.text: When its position changes with respect to surrounding objects.
When it is only moving up or down.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: What is the difference between speed and velocity?

options.text: Speed includes direction, velocity does not.
Velocity includes direction, speed does not.
Speed is measured in m/s, velocity in cm/s.
There is no difference, they are synonyms.

explanation: Speed is related to distance (magnitude only), while velocity is related to the displacement (magnitude and direction). Therefore, velocity includes direction while speed does not[cite: 300, 302, 329].

text: If a car's speed decreases while its direction remains the same, what happens to its velocity?
explanation: Velocity changes by changing the speed while keeping the direction same. If speed decreases, velocity decreases[cite: 325, 329].

text: The resistance of an object to any change in its state of rest or motion is called:
explanation: Objects have some inertia[cite: 343, 361]. Newton's first law (law of inertia) explains this resistance to change.

text: Which of the following demonstrates an object at rest?

options.text: A stone lying on a hill.
A car driving on a highway.

explanation: A stone lying on a hill is given as an example of an object at rest[cite: 272].

text: If you walk 5 meters forward and then 5 meters backward, what is your total distance traveled?
explanation: Distance is the total length of the actual path travelled. So, 5 meters + 5 meters = 10 meters[cite: 305].

text: What is the relationship between inertia and the force required to move an object?

options.text: More inertia means less force is needed.
More inertia means more force is needed.
Inertia has no effect on the required force.
Force is only needed for objects with zero inertia.

explanation: Objects have some inertia. A static object does not move without the application of a force, and a greater mass (implying greater inertia) requires a greater force (e.g., table vs book)[cite: 339, 340, 343, 357, 358, 361].

text: If an object is moving, what must be true about its position?

options.text: It is changing with respect to its surroundings.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: Which of these pairs represents units for speed and velocity in the CGS system?
explanation: In the CGS system, the unit for speed and velocity is cm/s[cite: 299].

text: When an object is said to be in motion, it implies its position is changing relative to what?
explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance between initial and final positions, including direction. Stating '50 meters North' provides both magnitude and direction[cite: 272, 297].

text: Why do stationary objects resist moving without an external push or pull?

options.text: They are made of specific materials.

explanation: A static object does not move without the application of a force, because objects have some inertia[cite: 339, 343, 357, 361].

text: Which of the following is true about velocity and direction?

options.text: Direction is only relevant for distance.

explanation: Velocity depends on speed as well as direction[cite: 329].

text: The distance traveled in one direction by an object in unit time is called its:
explanation: The distance travelled in one direction by an object in unit time is called its velocity[cite: 302].

text: Which of the following is an example illustrating Newton's first law of motion?

options.text: A ball falling faster when dropped from a greater height.
A car accelerating as the engine revs up.
An electric fan continuing to rotate after being switched off.

explanation: An electric fan keeps on rotating for some time even after it is switched off. This example is used to introduce the concept of inertia, which is described by Newton's first law[cite: 342, 343, 345, 360, 361, 363].

text: What is the primary characteristic that determines if an object is 'at rest'?

options.text: Its position is stable relative to its surroundings.
It is in a state of free fall.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: If a person walks around a circular field and returns to their starting point, what is their displacement?

options.text: Equal to the circumference of the field.
Equal to the radius of the field.

explanation: If she starts from point A and takes one round, her displacement is zero because she returns to the starting point[cite: 295, 297].

text: Which of the following defines a 'unit time' for velocity?
explanation: Unit time can be one second, one minute, one hour, etc. If large units are used, one year can also be used as a unit of time[cite: 303].

text: What happens to the velocity of an object if both its speed and direction change?
explanation: Velocity changes by changing the direction as well as the speed[cite: 328, 329].

text: The phenomenon where fruits fall from a tree when its branches are shaken is an example of:
explanation: This example is given to explain that objects have some inertia[cite: 341, 343, 359, 361]. The fruits tend to remain at rest due to inertia.

text: Why is 'motion' considered a 'relative concept'?

options.text: Because it always involves two objects moving together.
Because its definition depends on the observer's frame of reference or surroundings.

explanation: You have learnt that motion is a relative concept. If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: What is the key characteristic of an object moving in a straight line regarding its speed and velocity?

options.text: Speed is zero, velocity is non-zero.
Velocity is zero, speed is non-zero.

explanation: If the motion is along a straight line, the values of speed and velocity are the same[cite: 301].

text: An object at rest tends to remain at rest. This is due to:
explanation: A static object does not move without the application of a force...objects have some inertia[cite: 339, 343, 357, 361].

text: What does a 'stationary train' exemplify in the context of motion?
explanation: A stationary train is listed as an example of an object at rest[cite: 272].

text: If a person runs around a park and ends up back where they started, their displacement is:
explanation: When an object returns to its starting point, its displacement is zero[cite: 297].

explanation: We have learnt that inertia is related to the mass of the object. Newton’s first law of motion describes this very property[cite: 343, 344, 345, 361, 362, 363].

options.text: Change in velocity per unit time.

text: If an object's position is changing relative to its surroundings, it is said to be in:
explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: Which of the following scenarios describes an object at rest?

options.text: A car accelerating from a stoplight.
A book sitting on a table.
A bird flying across the sky.

explanation: A book sitting on a table, if its position is not changing relative to the table or room, is at rest (similar to a stationary train or stone on a hill)[cite: 272, 265, 266].

text: When comparing speed and velocity, the unit of measurement is:

options.text: Different in SI system, same in CGS system.
Same in SI system, different in CGS system.
Same in both SI and CGS systems.

text: A car starts from rest, travels 100 km, and then stops. What is its final displacement relative to its starting point?
explanation: Assuming it travels in a straight line and stops at a point 100 km away from its starting point, its displacement would be 100 km in the direction of travel. This is a basic application of displacement definition[cite: 272, 297].

options.text: A ball thrown in the air.

explanation: Sometimes we cannot see the motion of an object directly, as in the case of a breeze[cite: 267].

explanation: Displacement is the net change in position. 50 km East - 30 km West = 20 km East[cite: 272, 297].

text: The definition 'distance travelled in one direction by an object in unit time' refers to:
explanation: The distance travelled in one direction by an object in unit time is called its velocity[cite: 302].

text: What is the reason that a book is easier to lift than a table?

options.text: Books have less mass and thus less inertia.
Tables are always fixed to the floor.
Books are designed to be moved.

explanation: The force which is sufficient to lift a book from a table is not sufficient to lift the table. This is because objects have some inertia, which is related to their mass. text: Which of the following describes an object in a state of 'rest'?

options.text: Its position is unchanging relative to its observation point.
It is moving at a constant speed.

explanation: If the position of an object is not changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be at rest[cite: 265, 266].

text: What is the most fundamental definition of 'motion'?

options.text: Movement from one place to another.
Change in position with respect to surroundings.

explanation: If the position of an object is changing with respect to its surroundings, then it is said to be in motion[cite: 265].

text: If a car is travelling around a roundabout at a constant speed, its speed is constant but its velocity is changing. This is because:

options.text: The direction of motion is continuously changing.

explanation: Velocity depends on both speed and direction. If the direction changes (as in a roundabout), the velocity changes even if the speed is constant[cite: 327, 329].

text: According to the Law of Inertia, an object in motion will continue in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by:
explanation: Newton's first law of motion (law of inertia) states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. This is implied by the examples like static objects not moving without force[cite: 339, 345, 357, 363].

text: If a person walks 10 meters East, then 10 meters North, what is the magnitude of their displacement?
explanation: This forms a right triangle with legs of 10m each. Displacement is the hypotenuse, calculated by the Pythagorean theorem: sqrt(10^2 + 10^2) = sqrt(200) = 10 * sqrt(2) approximately 14.14 meters. This question tests the conceptual understanding of displacement as the shortest path[cite: 272, 297].

text: Which quantity provides information about both the rate of motion and its direction?
explanation: Velocity is the distance travelled in one direction by an object in unit time, and depends on speed as well as direction[cite: 302, 329].

text: An object's state of motion (or rest) will not change unless acted upon by a net external force. This is a statement of:

options.text: The law of conservation of energy.

explanation: Newton’s first law of motion describes inertia, which states that objects resist changes in their state of motion or rest without external force[cite: 339, 345, 357, 363].

text: If a car's speed is constant, but it is making a turn, is its velocity constant?

options.text: No, because its direction is changing.
Only if the turn is very sharp.
Only if there is no acceleration.

explanation: Velocity depends on speed as well as direction. If the direction changes, even with constant speed, the velocity changes[cite: 327, 329].

text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
explanation: Distance is the total length of the actual path travelled and does not include direction, making it a scalar quantity. Displacement, velocity, and force are vector quantities[cite: 305].

text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
explanation: Displacement is the shortest distance between initial and final positions with direction, making it a vector quantity. Distance, speed, and time are scalar quantities[cite: 272, 297, 300].

text: An object maintains its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force. This principle is directly related to:
explanation: This statement is the definition of Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the Law of Inertia[cite: 339, 345, 357, 363].

text: What is light?

options.text: A form of energy that causes sensation of sound.
A form of energy that causes sensation of vision.
A type of force that attracts objects.
A substance that has mass and occupies space.

explanation: Light is an agent which gives us information about what is happening in our surroundings and is actually electromagnetic radiation which causes the sensation of vision[cite: 6].

text: What phenomenon allows us to see objects around us?
explanation: It is only because of light that we can see the lush green vegetation, colourful flowers, deep blue skies in the day, stars shining in the dark night sky in the beautiful world around us. We can see the man-made objects in our surroundings as well. Light reflects differently from the various surfaces around us[cite: 6].

text: What is a mirror in scientific language?

options.text: A surface that absorbs all light.
A surface that emits its own light.
A surface which reflects light and creates clear images.
A transparent surface that allows light to pass through.

explanation: In scientific language, a surface which reflects light and creates clear images is called a mirror. A mirror is a reflecting surface[cite: 6].

text: What are the two main types of mirrors?
explanation: Mirrors are of two types: plane mirrors and spherical mirrors[cite: 6]. Spherical mirrors are a type of curved mirror[cite: 6].

text: How is a typical plane mirror made?

options.text: By painting a glass piece with black ink.
By coating the front surface of a glass with plastic.
By coating the back surface of a flat glass piece with a thin, reflecting film of aluminium or silver.
By engraving patterns on a metal sheet.

explanation: A mirror is made by coating the back surface of a flat and smooth glass piece with a thin, reflecting film of aluminium or silver[cite: 6].

text: What material is used to protect the reflecting film on the back of a mirror?
explanation: To protect this reflecting film and to make that side opaque, another coat of a substance like lead oxide is given over it[cite: 6].

text: Who made the first mirror by coating a plane surface of ordinary glass with silver metal?
explanation: The German scientist Justus von Liebig coated the plane surface of a piece of ordinary glass with silver metal and made the first mirror[cite: 6].

text: What kind of reflection occurs from smooth, flat surfaces?
explanation: We have already learnt that the reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection while rough surfaces reflect light irregularly[cite: 6].

text: Why are polished surfaces needed for reflecting light effectively?

options.text: Because they absorb less light and so maximum light gets reflected.
Because they are easier to clean.

explanation: We need polished surfaces for reflecting light. This is because polished surfaces absorb less light and so maximum light gets reflected[cite: 6].

text: When light rays fall perpendicularly on a plane mirror, how are they reflected?

options.text: They are absorbed by the mirror.
They pass through the mirror without reflection.
They are reflected back in the perpendicular direction.

explanation: As figure 11.2 A shows, light rays falling perpendicularly on the mirror are reflected back in the perpendicular direction[cite: 6].

text: What type of image is formed when reflected rays do not actually meet but appear to come from a point behind the mirror?
explanation: The reflected rays do not actually meet. Hence, such an image is called a virtual image[cite: 6].

text: For a plane mirror, how does the perpendicular distance of the image from the mirror compare to the perpendicular distance of the source from the mirror?

options.text: The image distance is half the source distance.
The image distance is double the source distance.
The image distance is equal to the source distance.
The image distance is unrelated to the source distance.

explanation: The perpendicular distance of the image from the mirror is equal to the perpendicular distance of the source from the mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the size of the image formed by a plane mirror compared to the source?

options.text: Depends on the distance of the source

explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is of the same size as the source[cite: 6].

text: What is lateral inversion?

options.text: When an image is formed upright and real.
When the image of every point on an object is formed behind the mirror at the same distance from the mirror as the point itself, causing a left-right reversal.
When an image is smaller than the object.

explanation: The image of every point on the word is formed behind the mirror at the same distance from the mirror as the point itself. This is called lateral inversion[cite: 6].
