Half the height of the person
One-fourth the height of the person

explanation: In order to see the full image of a person standing in front of a mirror, the minimum height of the mirror must be half the height of the person[cite: 6].

text: If two plane mirrors are placed parallel to each other, how many images will be seen?
explanation: If we keep the mirrors parallel to each other, infinite images will be seen[cite: 6].

text: What is a spherical mirror?

options.text: A flat piece of glass coated with silver.
A part of a hollow glass sphere with a shiny coated surface.
A mirror that always forms virtual images.
A mirror used to magnify objects.

explanation: Generally, spherical mirrors are parts of a hollow glass sphere like the part B in the figure. The inner or outer surface of this part is coated with a shiny substance to produce a spherical mirror[cite: 6].

text: What happens to your face in the mirrors displayed in a Laughing Chamber?

options.text: It appears larger but not distorted.

explanation: You must have seen the mirrors displayed in the Laughing Chamber in a fair. Your face appears distorted in these mirrors[cite: 6].

text: Which type of mirror has its inner surface as the reflecting surface?
explanation: If the inner surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface, then it is called a concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: Which type of mirror has its outer surface as the reflecting surface?
explanation: If the outer surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface then it is called a convex mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the pole of a spherical mirror?

options.text: The edge of the mirror surface.
The center of the mirror surface.
The point where all reflected rays meet.
The focal point of the mirror.

explanation: Pole: The centre of the mirror surface is called its pole[cite: 6].

text: What is the center of curvature of a spherical mirror?

options.text: The point on the mirror surface.
The center of the sphere of which the mirror is a part.
The point where the principal axis intersects the mirror.
The point where the image is formed.

explanation: Centre of curvature: The centre of the sphere of which the mirror is a part, is called the centre of curvature of the mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the radius of curvature of a spherical mirror?

options.text: The distance from the pole to the focal point.
The radius of the sphere of which the mirror is a part.
The distance from the object to the image.

explanation: Radius of curvature: The radius of the sphere of which the mirror is a part, is called the radius of curvature of the mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the principal axis of a spherical mirror?

options.text: A curved line passing through the pole.
A straight line passing through the pole and center of curvature.
A line parallel to the reflected rays.
The line representing the mirror surface.

explanation: Principal axis: The straight line passing through the pole and centre of curvature of the mirror is called its principal axis[cite: 6].

text: For a concave mirror, where do incident rays parallel to the principal axis meet after reflection?

options.text: At a particular point in front of the mirror on the principal axis (principal focus).

explanation: Incident rays which are parallel to the principal axis of a concave mirror, after reflection from the mirror, meet at a particular point in front of the mirror on the principal axis. This point (F) is called the principal focus of the concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: For a convex mirror, where do incident rays parallel to the principal axis appear to come from after reflection?

options.text: From a particular point behind the mirror lying along the principal axis (principal focus).
From a point in front of the mirror.

explanation: In the case of a convex mirror, incident rays parallel to the principal axis, after reflection, appear to come from a particular point behind the mirror lying along the principal axis. This point is called the principal focus of the convex mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is focal length (f) of a spherical mirror?

options.text: The distance from the center of curvature to the pole.
The distance between the pole and the principal focus of the mirror.
The distance from the object to the mirror.
The distance from the image to the mirror.

explanation: Focal length: The distance (f) between the pole and the principal focus of the mirror is called the focal length[cite: 6].

text: How is the focal length (f) of a spherical mirror related to its radius of curvature (R)?
explanation: This distance [focal length] is half of the radius of curvature of the mirror[cite: 6]. So, f = R/2.

text: What does magnification (M) due to a spherical mirror tell us?

options.text: The distance of the object from the mirror.
The focal length of the mirror.
How large the image is as compared to the object.

explanation: The magnification due to a spherical mirror is given by the ratio of the height of the image (h2) to the height of the object (h1). This tells us how large the image is as compared to the object[cite: 7].

text: When an object is kept above the principal axis, what is generally taken as the sign of its height (h1) in mirror calculations?
explanation: As the object is always kept above the principal axis, its height is always taken to be positive[cite: 7].

text: For which type of images is the height positive?
explanation: For virtual images, the height is positive while for real images, it is negative[cite: 7].

text: When an object is kept on the left of the mirror, what is the sign of its distance (u)?
explanation: As the object is kept on the left of the mirror, its distance (u) is always negative[cite: 7].

text: What is a real image?

options.text: An image that cannot be obtained on a screen.
An image formed by the apparent intersection of reflected rays.
An image in front of the mirror which can be obtained on a screen.
An image that is always upright.

explanation: The image in front of the mirror which can be obtained on a screen is called a real image[cite: 7].

text: Which type of mirror is commonly used as a rear view mirror in cars?
explanation: The rear view mirrors in cars, which enable drivers to see the vehicles coming from behind, are curved mirrors[cite: 6]. Curved mirrors like convex mirrors provide a wider field of view, which is why they are used as rear-view mirrors.

text: What is the primary characteristic of light that causes the sensation of vision?
explanation: Light is actually electromagnetic radiation which causes the sensation of vision[cite: 6].

text: Which property of light is responsible for seeing colorful flowers and the blue sky?
explanation: It is only because of light that we can see the lush green vegetation, colourful flowers, deep blue skies in the day, stars shining in the dark night sky in the beautiful world around us[cite: 6]. This implies the role of reflection in seeing objects.

text: What type of surface reflects light irregularly?
explanation: We have already learnt that the reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection while rough surfaces reflect light irregularly[cite: 6].

text: Why is a lead oxide coating applied to the back of a mirror?

options.text: To make the reflecting film opaque and protect it.

explanation: To protect this reflecting film and to make that side opaque, another coat of a substance like lead oxide is given over it[cite: 6].

text: What type of image is formed by a plane mirror?
explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is virtual and laterally inverted (upright in terms of vertical orientation)[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following English alphabet letters would form an image that looks the same as the original letter in a plane mirror?
explanation: Letters like A, H, I, M, O, T, U, V, W, X, Y do not show lateral inversion[cite: 6].

text: What happens when an extended source is used instead of a point source with a mirror?

options.text: Only a point image is formed.
An image is formed of every point of the source, forming an extended image.

explanation: If we use an extended source instead of a point source, an image is formed of every point of the source, thereby forming an extended image of the whole source[cite: 6].

text: What type of mirrors are generally parts of a hollow glass sphere?
explanation: Generally, spherical mirrors are parts of a hollow glass sphere[cite: 6].

text: What is the common characteristic of mirrors found in a 'Laughing Chamber'?
explanation: These mirrors are different from the mirrors we have at home. They are curved[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following is true about the images formed by curved mirrors compared to plane mirrors?
explanation: The images formed by curved mirrors are different from those formed by plane mirrors[cite: 6].

text: Where is the pole (P) located on a spherical mirror?

options.text: At the edge of the mirror.
At the exact center of the mirror surface.

explanation: Pole: The centre of the mirror surface is called its pole[cite: 6].

text: If the radius of curvature of a spherical mirror is 20 cm, what is its focal length?
explanation: The focal length is half of the radius of curvature of the mirror. So, f = R/2 = 20 cm / 2 = 10 cm[cite: 6].

text: When is the height of an image considered negative in mirror calculations?
explanation: For virtual images, the height is positive while for real images, it is negative[cite: 7].

text: Which type of mirror can produce a real image?
explanation: The text discusses real images in the context of spherical mirrors, specifically concave mirrors, where incident rays can meet at a point[cite: 7]. Plane mirrors only form virtual images[cite: 6]. Convex mirrors only form virtual images.

text: What is the angle of incidence equal to the angle of reflection?

options.text: According to the laws of reflection

explanation: Incident rays OR1 and OR2 get reflected according to the laws of reflection[cite: 6]. The laws of reflection state that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.

text: What is the primary role of a mirror?
explanation: A mirror is a reflecting surface[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following is NOT a type of reflection mentioned in the text?
explanation: The text mentions regular and irregular reflection[cite: 6]. Refraction is a different phenomenon not categorized as a type of reflection.

text: In a plane mirror, where does the image of a point source appear to come from?

options.text: From a point in front of the mirror.
From a point on the mirror surface.
From a point behind the mirror.
From the eye of the observer.

explanation: Due to reflection, they appear to be coming from a point behind the mirror. That point is the image of the point source[cite: 6].

text: When an object is placed in front of a plane mirror, what is the nature of the image?
explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is virtual and laterally inverted (which means it's erect vertically)[cite: 6].

text: What is the formula for the number of images (n) formed by two inclined plane mirrors with an angle (A) between them?
explanation: n = 360 / A - 1, where n = number of images, A = angle between the mirrors[cite: 6].

text: What type of mirror is part of a hollow glass sphere and has its inner surface as the reflecting surface?
explanation: If the inner surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface, then it is called a concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: In a concave mirror, where is the principal focus located?

options.text: In front of the mirror on the principal axis

explanation: Incident rays which are parallel to the principal axis of a concave mirror, after reflection from the mirror, meet at a particular point in front of the mirror on the principal axis. This point (F) is called the principal focus of the concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: In a convex mirror, where do parallel rays appear to diverge from after reflection?

options.text: A point in front of the mirror
A point behind the mirror along the principal axis

explanation: In the case of a convex mirror, incident rays parallel to the principal axis, after reflection, appear to come from a particular point behind the mirror lying along the principal axis. This point is called the principal focus of the convex mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the relation between the height of the image (h2) and the height of the object (h1) for magnification (M)?
explanation: The magnification due to a spherical mirror is given by the ratio of the height of the image (h2) to the height of the object (h1)[cite: 7].

text: Which type of image can be obtained on a screen?
explanation: The image in front of the mirror which can be obtained on a screen is called a real image[cite: 7].

text: What distinguishes spherical mirrors from plane mirrors?

options.text: Spherical mirrors are curved, while plane mirrors are flat.
Spherical mirrors only form virtual images.
Spherical mirrors are made of wood.

explanation: Spherical mirrors are parts of a hollow glass sphere (curved)[cite: 6], while plane mirrors are flat[cite: 6].

text: If an object is placed at the center of curvature of a concave mirror, what is the nature of the image formed?
explanation: While not explicitly stated in the provided text for all cases, a fundamental property of concave mirrors is that an object placed at the center of curvature forms a real, inverted image of the same size at the center of curvature. This is a basic concept in reflection of light.

text: When light travels from one medium to another, what phenomenon occurs?
explanation: Light rays change their direction as they enter a lens from the atmosphere and again when they enter the atmosphere after passing through the lens. This is called refraction[cite: 11]. Although this is from the 'Observing Space' chapter, it's a fundamental concept related to light.

text: What kind of image is always formed by a convex mirror?
explanation: Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect, and diminished images, as they diverge parallel rays[cite: 6].

text: What is the phenomenon of light bouncing off a surface called?
explanation: What is meant by reflection of light? [cite: 6]

text: Which type of mirror is used in households for daily activities?
explanation: Plane mirrors are used in various activities in our day to day life[cite: 6]. We see a clear image of ourselves when we stand in front of a mirror in our house[cite: 6].

text: What is the path of a light ray that passes through the principal focus of a concave mirror after reflection?

options.text: It goes through the center of curvature.
It becomes parallel to the principal axis.
It goes back along the same path.

explanation: This is a standard ray diagram rule for concave mirrors. A ray passing through the principal focus becomes parallel to the principal axis after reflection.

text: What happens to a light ray directed towards the center of curvature of a spherical mirror after reflection?

options.text: It becomes parallel to the principal axis.
It passes through the principal focus.
It reflects back along the same path.

explanation: This is a standard ray diagram rule. A ray passing through (or directed towards) the center of curvature strikes the mirror normally and reflects back along the same path.

text: If an object is placed at infinity from a concave mirror, where is the image formed?
explanation: Parallel rays from infinity converge at the principal focus of a concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: What type of image is formed by a concave mirror when the object is placed between the pole and the principal focus?
explanation: This is a specific case for concave mirrors where the image formed is virtual, erect, and magnified, located behind the mirror.

text: Which of the following is an example of a natural phenomenon we can enjoy because of light?
explanation: We can enjoy various wonders of nature like the sunrise, sunset and rainbow only because there is light[cite: 6].

text: What is the property of light that allows us to see things?
explanation: Light reflects differently from the various surfaces around us. We can see the man-made objects in our surroundings as well[cite: 6].

text: What material is typically coated on the back of a mirror for reflection?
explanation: A mirror is made by coating the back surface of a flat and smooth glass piece with a thin, reflecting film of aluminium or silver[cite: 6].

text: Which type of reflection occurs from rough surfaces?
explanation: We have already learnt that the reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection while rough surfaces reflect light irregularly. Diffuse reflection is another term for irregular reflection[cite: 6].

text: When light rays from a point source fall on a plane mirror, what is the nature of the image formed?

options.text: It can be real or virtual depending on distance.

explanation: The reflected rays do not actually meet. Hence, such an image is called a virtual image[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following is true about the image formed by a plane mirror?

options.text: It is smaller than the object.
It is larger than the object.
It is of the same size as the source.
Its size varies with object distance.

explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is of the same size as the source[cite: 6].

text: If the angle between two plane mirrors is 120 degrees, how many images will be formed?
explanation: Using the formula n = 360/A - 1, where A = 120 degrees. n = 360/120 - 1 = 3 - 1 = 2[cite: 6].

text: If the angle between two plane mirrors is 90 degrees, how many images will be formed?
explanation: Using the formula n = 360/A - 1, where A = 90 degrees. n = 360/90 - 1 = 4 - 1 = 3[cite: 6].

text: Which type of mirror is useful for a wider field of view?
explanation: The rear view mirrors in cars, which enable drivers to see the vehicles coming from behind, are curved mirrors[cite: 6]. Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view due to their diverging nature.

text: What is the principal focus of a concave mirror?

options.text: A point where rays diverge from.
A point where parallel incident rays meet after reflection.
The center of the sphere from which the mirror was cut.

explanation: Incident rays which are parallel to the principal axis of a concave mirror, after reflection from the mirror, meet at a particular point in front of the mirror on the principal axis. This point (F) is called the principal focus of the concave mirror[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following describes the focal length of a spherical mirror?

options.text: Distance from pole to center of curvature.
Distance between the pole and the principal focus.
Distance from the principal axis to the mirror surface.

explanation: Focal length: The distance (f) between the pole and the principal focus of the mirror is called the focal length[cite: 6].

text: When is the height of a real image considered negative?
explanation: For virtual images, the height is positive while for real images, it is negative[cite: 7]. Real images formed by mirrors are typically inverted.

text: What happens to parallel rays of light hitting a convex mirror?

options.text: They converge at the principal focus.
They appear to diverge from the principal focus behind the mirror.
They reflect back along the same path.
They are absorbed by the mirror.

explanation: In the case of a convex mirror, incident rays parallel to the principal axis, after reflection, appear to come from a particular point behind the mirror lying along the principal axis[cite: 6].

text: Which type of mirror is formed if the outer surface of a hollow glass sphere is coated with a shiny substance?
explanation: If the outer surface of the spherical mirror is the reflecting surface then it is called a convex mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the common term for a mirror that creates clear images by reflecting light?
explanation: In scientific language, a surface which reflects light and creates clear images is called a mirror[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following features is NOT characteristic of a plane mirror image?
explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is of the same size as the source, laterally inverted, and virtual[cite: 6].

text: If you stand 2 meters in front of a plane mirror, how far behind the mirror will your image appear?
explanation: The perpendicular distance of the image from the mirror is equal to the perpendicular distance of the source from the mirror[cite: 6].

text: What type of radiation is light?
explanation: Light is actually electromagnetic radiation which causes the sensation of vision[cite: 6].

text: Why do polished surfaces reflect maximum light?
explanation: This is because polished surfaces absorb less light and so maximum light gets reflected[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following is an essential component for making a silvered glass mirror?
explanation: The German scientist Justus von Liebig coated the plane surface of a piece of ordinary glass with silver metal and made the first mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the general term for mirrors that are curved?
explanation: Mirrors are of two types: plane mirrors and spherical mirrors[cite: 6]. Spherical mirrors are curved[cite: 6].

text: The point where incident rays parallel to the principal axis of a convex mirror appear to diverge from is called its:
explanation: In the case of a convex mirror, incident rays parallel to the principal axis, after reflection, appear to come from a particular point behind the mirror lying along the principal axis. This point is called the principal focus of the convex mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the relationship between the focal length (f) and the radius of curvature (R) of a spherical mirror?
explanation: The focal length is half of the radius of curvature of the mirror. So, f = R/2, which means R = 2f[cite: 6].

text: Which type of image is formed when reflected rays actually meet?
explanation: The reflected rays do not actually meet. Hence, such an image is called a virtual image[cite: 6]. Conversely, if they do meet, it is a real image.

text: What happens to the image if an object is moved closer to a concave mirror, beyond the principal focus?
explanation: As an object moves closer to a concave mirror from a distance, the real image formed moves away from the mirror and becomes larger (up to the focal point). This is a standard concept for concave mirrors.

text: Which of the following is an example of an object that can be seen due to light reflecting from its surface?

options.text: A light bulb that is switched on.

explanation: It is only because of light that we can see the lush green vegetation, colourful flowers...[cite: 6]. Objects like green leaves do not produce their own light but reflect ambient light.

text: Why do polished surfaces absorb less light?

options.text: Their molecular structure allows less absorption.
They are designed to reflect more.

explanation: Polished surfaces absorb less light and so maximum light gets reflected[cite: 6]. This is due to their smooth and regular atomic arrangement, which minimizes energy dissipation.

text: What is the primary function of the protective coat of lead oxide on a mirror?

options.text: To make the reflecting film opaque and prevent damage.

explanation: To protect this reflecting film and to make that side opaque, another coat of a substance like lead oxide is given over it[cite: 6].

text: What term describes the reversal of the image from left to right in a plane mirror?
explanation: This is called lateral inversion[cite: 6].

text: If a person is 1.6 meters tall, what is the minimum height of a plane mirror needed to see their full image?
explanation: The minimum height of the mirror must be half the height of the person. So, 1.6 m / 2 = 0.8 m[cite: 6].

text: How do light rays travel from a point source?
explanation: Light rays travel in all directions from such a source[cite: 6].

text: Which type of mirror is shown to cause distorted images in a 'Laughing Chamber'?
explanation: Your face appears distorted in these mirrors. ... These mirrors are different from the mirrors we have at home. They are curved[cite: 6].

text: What is the center of the mirror surface called?
explanation: Pole: The centre of the mirror surface is called its pole[cite: 6].

text: Which term describes the distance between the pole and the principal focus of a mirror?
explanation: Focal length: The distance (f) between the pole and the principal focus of the mirror is called the focal length[cite: 6].

text: What is the main characteristic of regular reflection?

options.text: Light reflects from smooth, flat surfaces.
Light is absorbed by the surface.

explanation: The reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following is not a property of the image formed by a plane mirror?
explanation: The image formed by a plane mirror is virtual, erect, laterally inverted, and of the same size as the object. It is not magnified[cite: 6].

text: If two plane mirrors are placed at an angle of 60 degrees, how many images will be formed?
explanation: Using the formula n = 360/A - 1, where A = 60 degrees. n = 360/60 - 1 = 6 - 1 = 5[cite: 6].

text: What type of spherical mirror is used in car headlights to produce a strong, parallel beam of light?
explanation: Concave mirrors are used in headlights; when a light source is placed at their focus, they produce a strong, parallel beam of light. This is a common application of concave mirrors.

text: In the context of spherical mirrors, what is the 'principal axis'?

options.text: A curved line connecting the edges of the mirror.
The line that is perpendicular to the mirror surface at any point.
The straight line passing through the pole and center of curvature.
The line that connects the object to the image.

explanation: Principal axis: The straight line passing through the pole and centre of curvature of the mirror is called its principal axis[cite: 6].

explanation: This is a standard ray diagram rule for concave mirrors. When the object is beyond C, the image is formed between F and C, and it is real, inverted, and diminished.

text: What is the function of a plane mirror?

options.text: To reflect light to form clear images.

explanation: A mirror is a reflecting surface[cite: 6]. We see a clear image of ourselves when we stand in front of a mirror in our house[cite: 6].

text: Which of the following describes the reflection of light from a perfectly smooth and shiny surface?
explanation: The reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection[cite: 6]. Specular reflection is another term for regular reflection.

text: What kind of image is formed when light rays actually converge at a point after reflection?
explanation: The reflected rays do not actually meet. Hence, such an image is called a virtual image[cite: 6]. Therefore, if they do actually meet, it's a real image.

text: What is the relationship between the object distance (u) and image distance (v) for a plane mirror?
explanation: The perpendicular distance of the image from the mirror is equal to the perpendicular distance of the source from the mirror[cite: 6]. With the sign convention where object distance is negative (since it's on the left), the image distance for a virtual image behind the mirror would be positive, leading to v = -u.

text: Which of the following letters would appear laterally inverted in a plane mirror?
explanation: Letters like A, H, I, M, O, T, U, V, W, X, Y do not show lateral inversion[cite: 6]. 'P' would appear as a backward 'P' due to lateral inversion.

text: What is the term for the center of the sphere from which a spherical mirror is a part?
explanation: Centre of curvature: The centre of the sphere of which the mirror is a part, is called the centre of curvature of the mirror[cite: 6].

text: What is the primary difference in how light interacts with a polished surface versus a rough surface?

options.text: Polished surfaces absorb more light, rough surfaces reflect more.
Polished surfaces cause irregular reflection, rough surfaces cause regular reflection.
Polished surfaces cause regular reflection, rough surfaces cause irregular reflection.
Light does not interact with rough surfaces.

explanation: The reflection from smooth, flat surfaces is regular reflection while rough surfaces reflect light irregularly[cite: 6].

text: If the angle between two plane mirrors is 45 degrees, how many images will be formed?
explanation: Using the formula n = 360/A - 1, where A = 45 degrees. n = 360/45 - 1 = 8 - 1 = 7[cite: 6].

text: Which part of a spherical mirror's surface is coated with a shiny substance to produce reflection?

options.text: Either its outer or inner surface.

explanation: The inner or outer surface of this part is coated with a shiny substance to produce a spherical mirror. Reflection of light takes place either from its outer or inner surface[cite: 6].

text: What is the common term for a mirror that reflects light and creates clear images?
explanation: In scientific language, a surface which reflects light and creates clear images is called a mirror[cite: 6].

text: If a light ray passes through the principal focus of a concave mirror, how does it reflect?
explanation: This is a standard ray tracing rule for concave mirrors. A ray passing through the principal focus reflects parallel to the principal axis.

text: What is the purpose of the table given in the textbook for different angles between mirrors and number of images?

options.text: To show the relationship between angle and image formation.
To measure the height of objects.

explanation: Now change the angle between the mirrors as given in the following table and count the number of images each time. How is this number related to the measure of the angle? Discuss this relationship[cite: 6].

explanation: As the object is kept on the left of the mirror, its distance (u) is always negative[cite: 7].

text: Which of the following is true about the height of virtual images?

options.text: It depends on the object's position.

explanation: For virtual images, the height is positive while for real images, it is negative[cite: 7].

text: What type of image is formed by a plane mirror that cannot be obtained on a screen?
explanation: The reflected rays do not actually meet. Hence, such an image is called a virtual image[cite: 6]. The image in front of the mirror which can be obtained on a screen is called a real image[cite: 7]. Therefore, a virtual image cannot be obtained on a screen.

text: Which of the following is an application of a convex mirror?
explanation: Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view, making them suitable for security mirrors in shops or as rear-view mirrors in vehicles[cite: 6].

text: What was the primary reason early humans observed the night sky?
explanation: Early man noticed that the position of the stars changed with time and had something to do with the occurrence of seasons, which was necessary for agriculture. [cite: 444, 445]

text: Who is credited with making the first telescope?
explanation: In 1608, spectacle maker and researcher, Hans Lippershey discovered that seeing through two lenses kept one behind the other, seems to bring objects closer to us. He thus made the first telescope. [cite: 455]

text: Who first used the telescope for space observations in 1609?
explanation: Galileo made a telescope in 1609 and used it for space observations. [cite: 456]

text: What is the range of wavelengths for visible radiation that human eyes can see?
explanation: Our eyes can see only that light which has wavelengths between 400 nm to 800 nm. Such light is called visible radiation. [cite: 459, 461, 467]

text: What type of waves are light waves?
explanation: Light is an electromagnetic wave. [cite: 458]

text: What is a refracting telescope primarily made of?
explanation: Most optical telescopes are made with two or more lenses. Hence such telescopes are called refracting telescopes. [cite: 467, 471]

text: What is the main purpose of the objective lens in an optical telescope?

options.text: To collect the maximum amount of light

explanation: To collect the maximum amount of light coming from a heavenly object, the objective lens should be made as large as possible. [cite: 468, 474]

text: What is 'chromatic aberration' in refracting telescopes?
explanation: The images formed by lenses have errors of colours. This is called chromatic aberration. [cite: 478]

text: What type of mirrors are used in reflecting telescopes?
explanation: To overcome these difficulties, telescopes are made using concave mirrors. [cite: 483, 485]

text: What is an advantage of reflecting telescopes over refracting telescopes?

options.text: They are lighter for the same size
Images do not have errors of color

explanation: It is easier to make large mirrors as compared to making large lenses. The weight of a large mirror too is less than that of a lens of the same size. The images formed by mirrors do not have errors of colour. [cite: 487, 489, 490]

text: Name one type of reflecting telescope.
explanation: The reflecting telescopes are mainly of two types: Newtonian and Cassegrain. [cite: 492]

text: What type of telescope is used to receive radio waves from heavenly objects?
explanation: Many heavenly objects emit radio waves in addition to visible radiation. Hence, a special type of telescope is used to receive these rays. It is called a radio telescope. [cite: 503, 504]

text: What is the shape of the dishes used in radio telescopes?
explanation: It is made from one or more dishes of a particular parabolic shape. [cite: 505]

text: What discovery did Galileo make using his telescope regarding Jupiter?
explanation: Using his telescope, Galileo also discovered the moons of Jupiter. [cite: 458]

text: What is the unit used to measure wavelengths mentioned in the chapter?
explanation: Wavelengths are described in nanometers (nm), where 1 nm = 10^-9 m. [cite: 459, 466]
